This is not ready for review yet because it incorporates commits which are either already in trunk or in the clients branch.

@ijuma Thank you for the review. I have added a check to two existing tests, one for secure acls and another for insecure. There was an issue with `controller_epoch` - it was being created in `KafkaController` without any ACLs even though it is listed as a secure path in `ZkUtils`. I think it was an oversight and fixed it, but it will be good if you can check, just in case it was deliberate. Since the migrator tool does add ACL to it, the change shouldn't cause any issues.

Jenkins system test runs look broken at the moment (https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/840/). I ran `sanity_checks`, `zookeeper_security_upgrade_test` and `security_rolling_upgrade_test` locally and they passed. That covers a combination of with-acl and no-acl.
Call for second review @dguy @edenhill
LGTM
LGTM thanks.

About closing producers: the problem is, that we first close all tasks, than we flush all state (and still need the producer for this). Thus, we need to decouple closing tasks and closing producers. If you have any better idea (and introducing method 'closeProducers`) to make the code cleaner I am happy to do so.... \cc @ijuma @enothereska @dguy

We still can change the code, to let `RecordCollector` close the producer instead of the task -- but it does not really simplify it. IMHO, `RecordCollector` should be agnostic and only `StreamTask` should know about the difference of "at-least-once/exactly-once".

We also do have `StreamTask#closeTopology()` for keeping tasks open during rebalance. I guess, we could change the pattern to `closeAllTopologies()` - `closeStateStores` - `closeAllTasks` ?

Thanks for the review @ijuma!

For some context. The main changes for the producer are in `Sender` and in `TransactionState`. The `TransactionState` class has nearly all the code for handling transactions. 

Essentially, the producer continues to have a single background thread it uses to send requests. The main difference is that transactional RPCs have the highest priority: if there is any such request waiting to be sent or in flight, no `ProduceRequest`s are sent. 

The `TransactionState` maintains a queue of Transactional requests, ordered by priority. Some requests like `FindCoordinator` must always be sent first. Also `EndTxn` must always go last, etc. This class also manages chaining requests: so if we need to send to a coordinator, but don't have a coordinator yet, it will put the `FindCoordinator` request at the head of the queue. 

The `TransactionsTest` has all the tests for the new flows.

On the consumer side, things are much simpler. All the main logic is in the `Fetcher`  in the `PartitionRecords` sub class. Here we decide whether to drop batches based on the contents of the abort index received in the fetch request. 

The `FetcherTest` has new test cases for the consumer side fetcher changes.

Regarding the earlier comment on testing, I made a separate ticket and PR that adds controller integration tests:
ticket: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-5069
PR: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2853

I put the test in a separate PR with the intent of having the integration tests checked in before this PR so we can test for regressions when switching over to the single-threaded event queue model.

I merged this to trunk after fixing `assertSame` to `assertEquals` to unblock other work and because other reviewers were happy with the original solution. I still think the layering is not right and abstractions seem to be leaking, but I'll leave it to you guys to decide if it's worth cleaning that up in a subsequent PR.
@ijuma Oh. Wow. Did not expect that. Will do a follow up PR...
To clarify: since these methods are not public and more work is being done for KIP-129, it seemed OK to iterate via subsequent PRs instead of blocking this one.
Follow up PR is #2854

Follow up for #2773 -- this cleans up test mocks and add config constants.

I did not yet address the "close producer" issues -- feedback is welcome on what the best solution might be. See comments on #2773 for details.

\cc @enothereska @dguy @guozhangwang @ijuma
